title: 103_hr358
content: The Act is titled the "National Commission to Support Law Enforcement Act." Congressional findings are also included in the Act. The Congress recognizes the risks law enforcement officers face daily, the lack of support from the Federal Government, their role in combating drugs and crime, the increase in violent crime and drug use, and the need for a review of current issues in law enforcement. A comprehensive study of law enforcement issues, including the role of the Federal Government in supporting officers, working conditions, and responsibility for crime control, would help redefine relationships between the Federal Government, the public, and law enforcement officials. Establishment of the "National Commission to Support Law Enforcement" (referred to as the "Commission") with duties outlined. The Commission will study and recommend changes regarding law enforcement agencies and issues at Federal, State, and local levels, including funding, employment conditions, information-sharing systems, research and training, equipment and resources, and cooperation among agencies. The Commission will consult with law enforcement officers, local officials, and community leaders nationwide to gather information on key law enforcement issues, including the impact of the criminal justice system on law enforcement. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 25 members, including individuals from national law enforcement organizations representing officers and management. Appointments are made by various leaders in the House, Senate, and the President. The Commission consists of 25 members appointed by leaders in the House, Senate, and the President. Members include representatives from law enforcement organizations and individuals with academic expertise in law enforcement issues. The Commission consists of 25 members appointed by leaders in the House, Senate, and the President. This includes individuals from law enforcement organizations, academic experts in law enforcement issues, and representatives from State or local governmental entities appointed by various leaders. The Commission consists of 25 members appointed by leaders in the House, Senate, and the President. The Attorney General is appointed by the Speaker of the House, while a representative from a State or local governmental entity is appointed by the President. The Comptroller General oversees the methodology of the Commission's study, and members select a chairperson among themselves. Members receive no additional pay but are reimbursed for travel expenses. The Commission, consisting of 25 members appointed by various leaders, will operate in accordance with specific sections of the United States Code. Members must be appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission may procure temporary services from experts and consultants under section 3109(b) of title 5, United States Code. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission upon request. The Administrator of General Services will provide administrative support services as requested by the Commission. The Commission has powers outlined in section 7. The Commission, under section 7, has the authority to hold hearings, receive evidence, delegate actions, obtain information from federal agencies, accept gifts, and use the United States mails. Additionally, the Commission can procure temporary services from experts, request personnel from federal agencies, and receive administrative support services from the Administrator of General Services. The Commission will submit a report to Congress with findings and proposals within eighteen months of its appointment. It will cease to exist sixty days after submitting the report. Two titles from previous acts will be repealed.
